question: What is the difference between a home birth and a hospital birth?
context:
Important information about pregnancy
First appointment with the gynecologist
Pregnant women in Germany enjoy special protection and are entitled to advice, medical care and support with new purchases for the child.
If you are pregnant, you must first go to your gynecologist.
Have the preventive check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks after.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your job is retained and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day and may not perform heavy physical labor.
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of breastfeeding.
Midwives provide advice during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery.
Every woman can call on the help of a midwife.
Most services are covered by health insurance.
Website Midwives Association in German and English
You can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district here
Pregnancy counseling
Women and men can go there for free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning.
Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example.
The counseling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child.
Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek advice.

If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to a child allowance from birth until they reach the age of 18.
You are entitled to child benefit from the age of 18.
In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
In return, they do not work for a certain period of time.
Or they only work part-time.
Parental allowance is paid during this time.

question: What health insurance policies are there in Germany?
context:
The German healthcare system
German healthcare system
In Germany, many facilities are part of the healthcare system.
The healthcare system has three areas:
1. outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies.
"Outpatient" means that the patient goes home after treatment.
2. inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals.
"Inpatient" means that the patient stays in hospital for treatment.
3. health protection of the population through services provided by the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive services.
"Preventive" means: offers to maintain health and avoid becoming ill).
The outpatient and inpatient care services provide medical treatment for sick people.
Everyone is free to choose their own doctor or facility.
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfills many different tasks.
You can find a list here.
The public health department also fulfills preventive tasks.
For example, they provide information and advice on the subject of health.
This should enable a healthy life in the district.
The health department organizes many projects at schools.
These projects provide information on the topic of "health" in a fun way.
They explain what is important for a healthy life.
You can find more information about the health department here.
You can find offers for health promotion and prevention here.
Good to know
Hospitals treat seriously ill and life-threateningly injured people.
So they will help you in an emergency!
For minor injuries or illnesses, go to a doctor's surgery.
You will get good help there.
You may need a doctor at night or at the weekend.
But it is not always an emergency.
You can then go to the medical on-call service.

question: What documents are required for a Schengen visitor visa?
context:

Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
Here you can get more information (also in English)
Please note that you must leave the country within the period of validity of your visa.
You must leave the Schengen area to do this.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified.
These can be reasons:
force majeure,
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.
If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

Registration for people in private accommodation or in decentralized asylum accommodation
Ukranian refugees live in private apartments.
Or in decentralized asylum accommodation.
They are all registered with the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Registration procedure
This is how registration works:
1. fill in the form
You fill out the form for a simplified initial registration.
A few days later you will receive a certificate by post.
With the certificate you can then look for work.
2. presentation at the Office for Foreigners and Integration
Arrange a personal appointment at the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Go to this page: Online appointment system
Select "Residence permit for humanitarian reasons (asylum)".
Then select the alphabetical assignment of your surname (last name).
In the online appointment system you will find all the appointments of the Foreigners' Registration Office for the next four weeks.
If no dates are displayed, all dates are fully booked.
New dates are added regularly.
Try again at a later date!
You should be patient.
Many people need an appointment at the moment.
For the appointment you need:
Passport and birth certificate (alternatively: other proof of identity that proves your origin from Ukraine)
If available: Allocation notice for the district of Augsburg
Registration of residence with the responsible residents' registration office
Biometric photograph
3. register residence
Register your place of residence.
You do this with your municipality.
Please make an appointment at the Residents' Registration Office.
Registration after arrival at the anchor center
Ukrainians without private accommodation can find a first point of contact at the ANKER Center of the Swabian government.
Here you will find the ANKER Center.
People without private accommodation should register there.
This is the first important step towards obtaining a humanitarian residence permit.
Registration takes place on site at the ANKER facility in Swabia.
Those registered receive a so-called "white paper".
This is the basis for further necessary steps and official procedures.
You can find the most important questions on entry and residence on the website of the Federal Ministry of the Interior here.
Unaccompanied refugee minors
More and more people are having to leave their homes because of the war in Ukraine.
Among them were numerous accompanied and unaccompanied children and young people.
The Office for Youth and Family Affairs is looking for people who take in children and young people without a legal guardian.
Some people have accompanied children and young people to Germany without their parents.
They should contact the Office for Youth and Family Affairs.
You can find a sample power of attorney for custody here:
Parental power of attorney

question: What documents are required for asylum procedures?
context:
Residence documents
Residence permit - flight / asylum
Every person who comes to Germany to apply for asylum receives a residence document.
It is often referred to as an "ID card".
The residence document provides information about the status in the asylum procedure and whether there are any restrictions on gainful employment (When am I allowed to work?).
There are five different documents:
1. proof of arrival
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to persons who have applied for asylum.
Valid for the period between registration as an asylum seeker or
asylum seeker and official application for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
2. residence permit
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made on the asylum application.
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) decides on the asylum application.
If the application for asylum is rejected as unfounded, there is the option of lodging a complaint with the administrative court.
The stay is deemed to be permitted until the decision of the administrative court.
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, residence and, if applicable, spatial restrictions.
If a work permit is required, this can be applied for at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement: "" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office
3. fictitious certificate
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: Certificate for the period from the positive decision on the asylum procedure until the residence permit is issued (fiction of permission) or for a phase of review or extension of documents (fiction of continued validity).
4. residence permit
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: positive decision on the asylum application
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is issued for the purposes specified in the Residence Act.
There are various residence permits for refugees on humanitarian grounds.
Opens up the possibility of a later permanent right of residence (settlement permit)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Responsibility for job placement and social benefits: "" Jobcenter
5. acquiescence
Status: Tolerated
Background: negative decision on the asylum application
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation.
It is issued temporarily if deportation is impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
General toleration regulation possible for certain groups by order of the highest state authority for a maximum period of 3 months ("deportation stop")
Work permit is generally required, application at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement:"" Employment Agency

question: What are the penalties for violating the Measles Protection Act?
context:
Measles Protection Act
All children must be vaccinated or immune against measles.
The parents must provide proof.
This obligation also applies to children who are cared for in a children's home for at least four weeks.
And also for children in refugee accommodation.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases.
This is why almost all people without vaccination protection become infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in children under five and adults over 20.
Inflammation of the middle ear or lungs and diarrhea are among the most common symptoms.
When are vaccinations given?
1st vaccination: Between the age of 11 and the age of 18.
and 14.
Month of life (after the 9th month at the earliest)
2nd vaccination: before the 2nd birthday at the latest
The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and possibly
Chickenpox.
Further information on the measles vaccination can be found at: https://www.masernschutz.de/

question: What is the difference between statutory and private health insurance?
context:
Health insurance and health insurance
Insurance is compulsory in Germany.
This means that you must be a member of a health insurance fund in order to see a doctor.
As soon as you have a residence permit, you must register with a regular health insurance fund.
You can choose and change your health insurance company yourself.
You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are therefore entitled to the same benefits as all residents in Germany.
Always take your insurance card with you to your doctor's appointments.
Here you will find an overview of health insurance companies in Germany.
The basic medical care provided by the health insurance fund includes
Benefits for the prevention and alleviation of illness
Pregnancy benefits
Services for the detection of diseases
Benefits for the treatment of illnesses
Costs
When you go to a doctor, show your health insurance card.
With this, most examinations are free of charge for you.
You must pay for certain preventive medical check-ups yourself.
You will have to pay part of the costs for therapies (e.g. physiotherapy) and aids (e.g. bandages) yourself.
People who have little money can be exempted.
Ask your health insurance company about this.
The costs of dental treatment are covered by health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs for treatment in hospital are also paid by the health insurance company.
However, you must pay a daily hospital allowance of €10 for each day in hospital.
People who have little money can be exempted.

Forms of protection during the asylum procedure
If you make an application for asylum, you apply to receive protection in Germany and not be deported.
The law anticipates several forms of protection.
They correspond to different forms of persecution in your home country.
In an asylum procedure, we check which forms of protection you can be given depending on your individual situation.
You can find a short overview of the different forms of protection below.
Via the links given you can find more detailed information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Entitlement to asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Grundgesetz (basic law or GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany, people who are politically persecuted receive asylum.
This protection status can be given to people who, according to their
Ethnicity
Nationality
Political opinions
Fundamental religious outlook or
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
would be faced with persecution in their country of origin and, therefore, face serious violations of human rights if they returned.
Find out more
Protection of refugees
According to the Geneva Convention on Refugees, people are regarded as refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution owing to one of the follow characteristics and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
Political opinions
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
Legal basis: Section 3 par.
German Asylum Law (AsylG)
Find out more
Subsidiary protection
People are entitled to subsidiary protection if they are threatened with serious harm in their country of origin and are not able to utilise the protection of their country of origin.
The threat can be from the state or also from a non-state element.
Examples include:
Death penalty
Torture
Inhuman or humiliating treatment or punishment
Serious individual danger to life or intactness of a civil person owing to arbitrary violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: Section 4 par.
1 German Asylum Law (AsylG)
Find out more
National deportation ban
A person seeking protection must not be deported if
the deportation means breaking the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Basic freedoms (EMRK) or
there is a significant concrete danger to body, life or freedom in the destination country.
Legal basis: Section 60 par.

question: Who can I contact for help if I'm a victim of illegal employment?
context:

Irregular and illegal employment
A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
It can be punished with fines and prison!
If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment: A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
This is forbidden and against the law.
In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

question: At what age can children be vaccinated against TBE?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/

question: How can I find legal assistance for the asylum appeal procedure?
context:
Legal action
Legal action
You do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF?
Then you can sue.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant".
The BAMF is the "defendant".
In the event of an appeal, the Munich Administrative Court will review the BAMF's decision.
If it agrees with the BAMF, the case will be dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
If the administrative court does not agree with the BAMF, you will receive a residence permit.
The BAMF is then obliged to grant you protection.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision by the BAMF.
For example, if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: recognition of refugee status).
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: How many days per week do you learn theory in a dual apprenticeship?
context:
Dual apprenticeship
How does a dual apprenticeship work?
Candidates learn the theory at a vocational school (1 to 2 days per week) and the practical part at a company (3 to 4 days per week).
The training lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
Candidates receive a salary (just how much a person earns depends on the industry, company and year of the apprenticeship).
There are roughly 330 professions for which a candidate can undertake a dual apprenticeship.
Just how a dual apprenticeship works is explained in information films provided by the Bundesinstitut für Berufsbildung (Federal Institute for Vocational Education and Training) in 10 languages (Arabic, Chinese, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish).
How do I find an apprenticeship place?
If you want to complete a dual training programme, you first have to find a training place.
You are applying for a training place at a company (enterprise, firm, institution).
"training place" means: You have a job in a company,in whichyou learn the practical work for the profession.
Only then comes the registration for the vocational school.
The company takes care of the registration.
The following online job exchanges will help you find an apprenticeship:
Job exchange of the employment agency www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
IHK apprenticeship exchange www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de

through the "AzubiWelt" app of the Federal Employment Agency (www.arbeitsagentur.de/azubiwelt)
in newspapers,
on company websites,
through unsolicited applications.
Which vocational school should I attend?
In most cases, vocational schools have specialised in what they offer.
In the district of Augsburg there are, for example, two subject areas at the vocational school Staatliches Berufliches Schulzentrum Neusäß: Business and Administration (office, industry, retail, wholesale) and Agricultural Economics (agriculture, landscaping, floristry).
If you want to do dual training in a different field, you will attend a different vocational school.

Other holidays shift from year to year.
You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.
Summer vacation: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of vacation.

Intercultural calendar
The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.
Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is set forward by one hour from winter to summer time.
The clock is set back by one hour from summer to winter time.

question: What type of certificate is required for a settlement permit?
context:
Do I need a certificate?
Do I need a certificate?
In some situations it is necessary or very useful to have proof of German language skills.
For example:
Applying for an apprenticeship or job
If you can prove your German language skills, your chances of getting an apprenticeship or a job are higher.
If you have several competitors, you can be more convincing with a certificate.
Further vocational training or qualification
Vocational training courses often require a certain level of German.
You often have to prove this with a certificate.
Access to study at colleges and universities
To study at a college or university, you often have to prove your knowledge of German.
This is possible with one of the following certificates:
Language diploma of the
Conference of Ministers of Education and Cultural Affairs (second stage)
DSH2
TestDaf, level 4 in all 4 sub-areas.
Assessment test at a preparatory college.
This means that no further testing is necessary.
Certificates recognized by the Standing Conference of the Ministers of Education and Cultural Affairs of the Länder in the Federal Republic of Germany (KMK) or the German Rectors' Conference (HRK).
the exams at level C1 or C2 of the
Goethe-Institut
TestDaF certificates and telc certificates from the Munich Language and Interpreting Institute (SDI).
"telc German C1 University".
Completed degree in German studies (no pedagogy studies).
Graduation certificate from a grammar school, a preparatory college, a university of applied sciences or a university.
For a permanent residence permit (settlement permit)
To obtain a settlement permit, you must provide proof of sufficient German language skills.
This is possible, for example, with a certificate from a "" integration course "Deutsch-Test für Zuwanderer" (DTZ).
A German school-leaving certificate can also be proof of German language skills.
For naturalization (obtaining German citizenship)
In addition to sufficient knowledge of German, you must also demonstrate knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany.
You can do this, for example, with the "Living in Germany" test.
This test is the conclusion of the orientation course (part of the "" integration course).

question: What rights do I have as a newcomer in terms of personal freedom?
context:
Personal freedom
All adults are entitled to make their own decisions about themselves and their own lives.
Whether man or woman, young or old, with or without a disability, regardless of skin color or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict the freedom of others.
This means, for example:
Everyone can decide what they want to wear.
For example, women can decide whether they want to wear pants, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
For example, men can decide whether to wear a suit and tie, a T-shirt and jeans, a turban, a hat or a beard.
Everyone is allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people alone.
The state has no generally valid or religiously based dietary regulations.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
The consumption of alcohol by children and young people is prohibited.
Every woman and every man can decide for themselves whether and who they want to marry.
Every woman and every man is entitled to divorce.
Unmarried couples are allowed to live together and have children.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry and have children.
Contraception is permitted for both sexes.
A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.
Same-sex couples can marry.
The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For persons in the asylum procedure, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is recognized.

question: What is the lowest language level?
context:
Language levels
Language levels
There are different language levels.
In the language and integration courses, the levels according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages are used:
Language level A: elementary language use
Language level B: independent language use (necessary for training or work)
Language level C: competent use of the language (necessary for studies and certain professions)
A more precise distinction is usually made:
A1: Beginners
A2: Basic knowledge
B1: Advanced use of language
B2: Independent use of language
C1: Competent use of language
C2: Almost native speaker level
And even within these levels there are further differentiations (A1/1, A1/2, A2/1, A2/2, etc.)
The six levels mean in detail:
A1: Beginner
They can understand and use simple words and sentences.
You can introduce yourself and others.
For example: My name is Maria.
I am 30 years old.
I live in Germany.
This is my friend.
His name is Paul.
You can ask questions about yourself.
For example: What is your name?
Where do you live?
You can answer questions.
For example: How are you doing?
I'm fine.
You can talk to a person if they speak slowly and clearly.
A2: Basic knowledge
You can understand sentences and frequently used words.
You understand words in these areas: Personal and family information, shopping, work and your surroundings.
You can communicate in simple, everyday situations.
You can describe your background, education and environment.
B1: Advanced use of language
They can understand a lot when it comes to work, school or leisure, for example.
You can communicate while traveling.
You can say something about familiar topics and personal interests.
They can report on experiences and events.
You can describe dreams, hopes and goals.
You can give brief reasons or explanations for plans and views.
B2: Independent use of language
You can understand the most important content of complex texts on concrete and abstract topics.
You also understand technical discussions in your area of specialization.
You can communicate spontaneously and fluently.
A normal conversation with
Native speakers are able to communicate without much effort on either side.
You can express yourself clearly and in detail on many different topics.
You can explain a point of view on a current issue.
You can specify the advantages and disadvantages of different options.
C1: Professional language skills
You can understand a lot of demanding, longer texts.
They also capture implicit meanings.
You can express yourself spontaneously and fluently.
You rarely have to search for words.
You can use the language effectively and flexibly in social and professional life or in training and studies.
You can express yourself clearly, in a structured and detailed manner on complex issues.
In doing so, you use various means of linking texts appropriately.
C2: (Near) native speaker skills
You can understand practically everything you read or hear with ease.
You can summarize information from various written and oral sources.
You can reproduce reasons and explanations in a coherent presentation.
They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.
They can also make finer nuances of meaning clear in more complex situations.

question: What do the abbreviations LGBTQIA+ and LGBTTIQ mean?
context:

Gender diversity
Sexual orientation is a central aspect of one's personality.
In Germany, every person is allowed to choose their own sexual identity.
Every person is free to decide who they are with and who they love.
And every person is free to live out their own sexual orientation.
Because this is an important right, it is enshrined in law (General Equal Treatment Act).
In Germany, a great deal of effort is being made to break down rigid role models and open up the view to all ways of life.
A lot has therefore happened in recent years:
Regardless of whether gender reassignment from male to female or from female to male has taken place or is planned.
What does LGBTQIA+ or LGBT mean?
LGBTQIA+ or
LGBT are abbreviations from the English language.
In German, the abbreviation LSBTTIQ is often used, which stands for the following terms:
L=lesbian - S=gay - B=bisexual - T=transgender - T=transsexual - I=intersexual - Q=queer.
Lesbians are women who love other women.
Gays are men who love other men.
Bisexuals fall in love with people, regardless of gender.
Transgender people are women who were born in a male body or men who were born in a female body.
Like transgender people, transsexuals are born in the "wrong body" and change their appearance through hormones and operations.
Intersex people have both male and female genitals.
People with an asexual orientation have little or no interest in sexual activity.
Queer stands for everything that deviates from traditional gender roles and partner models.
The "+" in LGBTQIA+ means that there are even more sexual or gender identities.
Support
You will also find acceptance and support in the district of Augsburg.

question: What is gender equality in Germany?
context:
Equal rights for men and women
Women and men have the same rights.
Women and men have the same duties.
This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.
This means, for example:
Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons.
They take part in sports lessons together.
Women are allowed to study or learn a trade.
In principle, all professions are open to women.
Women take on responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in public offices and authorities.
Their instructions must be followed.
Women decide for themselves what kind of work they want to do.
They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.
Women do not have to ask their husband, parents or other family members for permission to work, open an account or conclude contracts.
Women are allowed to dress as they wish.
Women decide for themselves whether, when and whom they want to marry.
Mothers are particularly protected.
You must and may not work for six weeks before and eight weeks after the birth.
They may not be dismissed because of their maternity.
The tasks and roles in the family are not prescribed.
Women participate in public life.
They attend cultural, political or sporting events, restaurants and bars.
Women can vote and be elected to political office.
Women and men are equal in inheritance law, daughters as well as sons.
Sexual touching, comments or requests are only permitted if everyone involved agrees.
A "stop" or "no" must always be respected.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Any form of violence against women, including in marriage.
No one may be sexually harassed.
Rape, even within marriage, is punished.
No one may be forced to marry.
Coercion into marriage by force or threat is punishable.

question: When does your freedom end?
context:
Personal freedom
Personal freedom
All adults are entitled to make their own decisions about themselves and their own lives.
Whether man or woman, young or old, with or without a disability, regardless of skin color or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict the freedom of others.
This means, for example:
Everyone can decide what they want to wear.
Women can decide whether they want to wear pants, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
Men can decide whether to wear a suit and tie, a T-shirt and jeans, a turban, a hat or a beard.
Everyone is allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people alone.
The state has no generally valid or religiously based dietary regulations.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
The consumption of alcohol by children and young people is prohibited.
Every woman and every man can decide for themselves whether and who they want to marry.
Every woman and every man is entitled to divorce.
Unmarried couples are allowed to live together and have children.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry and have children.
Contraception is permitted for both sexes.
A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.
Same-sex couples can marry.
The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For persons in the asylum procedure, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is recognized.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent.
Any sexual activity with children is prohibited.
Private property is permitted for every man and every woman in Germany.
It is permitted to own a house or a plot of land.
Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.
Important:
One's own freedom ends where it infringes the freedom or human dignity of others or violates the law.

question: What kind of residence documents are there?
context:

Residence permit - flight / asylum
Every person who comes to Germany to apply for asylum receives a residence document.
It is often referred to as an "ID card".
The residence document provides information about the status in the asylum procedure and whether there are any restrictions on gainful employment (When am I allowed to work?).
There are five different documents:
1. proof of arrival
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to persons who have applied for asylum.
Valid for the period between registration as an asylum seeker or
asylum seeker and official application for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
2. residence permit
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made on the asylum application.
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) decides on the asylum application.
If the application for asylum is rejected as unfounded, there is the option of lodging a complaint with the administrative court.
The stay is deemed to be permitted until the decision of the administrative court.
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, residence and, if applicable, spatial restrictions.
If a work permit is required, this can be applied for at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement: "" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office
3. fictitious certificate
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: Certificate for the period from the positive decision on the asylum procedure until the residence permit is issued (fiction of permission) or for a phase of review or extension of documents (fiction of continued validity).
4. residence permit
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: positive decision on the asylum application
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is issued for the purposes specified in the Residence Act.
There are various residence permits for refugees on humanitarian grounds.
Opens up the possibility of a later permanent right of residence (settlement permit)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Responsibility for job placement and social benefits: "" Jobcenter
5. acquiescence
Status: Tolerated
Background: negative decision on the asylum application
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation.
It is issued temporarily if deportation is impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
General toleration regulation possible for certain groups by order of the highest state authority for a maximum period of 3 months ("deportation stop")
Work permit is generally required, application at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)

The German courses for initial language orientation (also known as initial orientation courses) teach both basic German language skills and information about life in Germany.

question: How can I complain about child abuse?
context:
Children's rights
Children and young people have rights.
These rights are set out in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
It also applies in Germany to all children and young people under the age of 18.
In addition, there are many laws in Germany that protect the life, health and rights of children in a special way.
The protection of children always comes first.
This means, for example:
All children have the same rights.
No matter where they live, where they come from, what color their skin is, what their parents do, what language they speak, what religion they are, whether they are boys or girls, what culture they live in, whether they have a disability, whether they are rich or poor.
Children have the right to a name, a birth certificate, a nationality and a family.
The state always helps when children are lacking something.
Children should be able to live with their parents, unless this puts them in danger.
Parents can and must care for their children, protect and promote their health and well-being.
Children who have fled have the right to special protection and help.
Children must be protected so that they can grow up well.
Children must and may go to school.
School attendance is compulsory.
Parents must support their children in attending school.
School education is free in Germany.
Children are allowed to form their own opinions.
At the age of 14 at the latest, children can decide for themselves whether they want to belong to a religion and which one.
Children should be able to develop well.
The parents are responsible for this.
If they need support, the state must help and provide food, clothing and housing, for example.
Children whose parents are not married have the same rights as children who live with married parents.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Children must not be neglected or abused.
Children must not be beaten or physically or mentally abused in any way.
Children are allowed up to the age of 13.
The following applies to employees under the age of 18
When they are older, they are only allowed to take on very limited work.
This must not impair their health and development.
Children may not be abducted or used as objects of trade.
It is forbidden to perform sexual acts on children.
Here you will find the rights of the child in various languages.
Contact point
Do you have a problem?

question: What types of permanent residence permits are there?
context:
Permanent residence
Permanent residence
Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit) according to Section 9 Aufenthaltsgesetz
With the Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit), you can live and work in Germany without time or location limits.
Requirements (selected):
Legal residence in Germany for at least five years (earlier study and training times are calculated at 50 percent)
Valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (study) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure living costs and housing
Proof of sufficient retirement planning (at least 60 months obligatory contributions or voluntary contributions to state pension insurance in Germany)
Sufficient German language knowledge and knowledge about the legal & societal rules and living conditions in Germany– usually proved by:
Confirmation that you have taken part in an integration course
or
Study certificates and references about completed job training in Germany or other language certificates
Further documents may be required in individual cases.
You can find more information on these requirements here.
Permanent residence – EU
The permission for permanent residence – EU (Daueraufenthalt – EU) is a permanent residence permit and offers the same rights as the Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit).
With the permission for permanent residence, you can live and work in Germany without time or location limits.
Furthermore, you can fundamentally also live, work or study in the countries of the European Union (with the exception of Ireland, Denmark, Great Britain), (special requirements apply for individual countries).
You can find more information on these requirements here.
Whether a Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit) or an Erlaubnis zum Daueraufenthalt– EU (permission for permanent residence) is better for you depends on your individual circumstances.
The »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) would be happy to advise you.

question: What is usually the payout amount on the payslip?

Name and address of the employer

Insurance number of the employer
Date of start of employment
Tax class and tax identification number
Billing period
Gross salary (salary without deductions - gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of supplements or allowances
Type and amount of deductions
Net amount (after all deductions)

question: Does the Jobcenter cover the rental costs?
context:
Cost absorption by the job center
Cost absorption by the job center
If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the Jobcenter, the Jobcenter pays the rent.
However, only if you are in need of help and the rent is reasonable (not too high).
Each job center sets its own upper rent limit, which can even vary within a jurisdiction (e.g.
B. Jobcenter Augsburg-Land).
Upper rent limit means: The Jobcenter sets a maximum amount for the rent.
If your rent is more expensive, you have to pay the rest yourself.
Here you can find more information about the rent cap in the district of Augsburg.
You can find the tables for the rent ceilings of the individual authorities here:
Jobcenter Augsburg City
Jobcenter Augsburg Land
What needs to be considered?
Important: If you have found an apartment and the rent is paid by the Jobcenter, you must not sign the rental agreement immediately.
The Jobcenter must check and approve the appropriateness of the accommodation costs before the contract is signed.
This is possible during regular opening hours without an appointment.
The Jobcenter's decision on appropriateness and acceptance of the deposit will be communicated immediately in a written rental confirmation.
It is important that a rental agreement or at least a rental offer with all the minimum details of the apartment is already available.
It is important to note that the tenancy agreement must already be signed by the landlord, but not by the tenant.
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit
Security deposit
The Jobcenter can grant the deposit on a loan basis upon application.
Loan basis means: you are lent the money and have to pay it back.
As a rule, this is unproblematic and is approved if the accommodation costs are reasonable.
The Jobcenter usually pays the deposit directly to the landlord or tenant.
paid by the landlord.
Repayment of the loan to the Jobcenter is automatically deducted from the monthly standard benefits (normally max.
ten percent) is deducted and retained.
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Jobcenter, you have the option of applying for initial furniture and furnishings.
You will be paid a lump sum according to the number of people, the size of the apartment and the equipment required.
The initial equipment includes furniture, curtains, mattresses, cooking utensils, dishes and, if not available in the apartment, stove, sink, refrigerator and washing machine.
It is important that the application is submitted before the furniture is purchased.
A list with an overview of where you can buy cheap and used furniture can be found "here.
Caution: It may take some time before the money is paid out!
In addition, the Jobcenter has the right (and uses this right) to inspect the apartment in order to check the amount of the initial equipment.
If it is determined that, for example, furniture is already present that has not been demonstrably (in writing!) borrowed (e.g.
B. emergency sleeping bed from SKM), you have no further claim to initial equipment for these items.
Info for refugees
When you move out of your accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture with you.
That's why you need new furniture.
You can submit an application for initial equipment to the Jobcenter.

question: How long is the minimum contract term for a fixed-term contract?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract last (e.g.
B.twelve or 24 months)?
If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost and how much does a cell phone without a contract cost?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?

question: What is meant by irregular employment?
context:

Irregular and illegal employment
Work that is paid but not registered with the tax office and health insurance fund and for which no taxes and social security contributions are therefore paid is illegal and is referred to as "irregular employment" in Germany.
Fines and prison sentences are threatened!
If someone receives social benefits or unemployment benefit but still works and conceals this from the social welfare office, employment agency or job center, this is called illegal employment: You receive state benefits even though you are in paid employment.
This is prohibited and against the law.
A colloquial term for this is "moonlighting".
Always inform the office from which you receive benefits if you wish to take up work;
It is permitted to earn money while receiving benefits (benefits will then be recalculated), but you are obliged to declare any earnings and income immediately.
Taking up employment despite a work ban is also considered illegal employment.
Depending on the country of origin and reason for residence, illegal employment can lead to an indefinite ban on working!

question: What religious freedom is there in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the Jobcenter, the Jobcenter pays the rent.

The Jobcenter must check and approve the appropriateness of the accommodation costs before the contract is signed.
This is possible during regular opening hours without an appointment.
The Jobcenter's decision on appropriateness and acceptance of the deposit will be communicated immediately in a written rental confirmation.
It is important that a rental agreement or at least a rental offer with all the minimum details of the apartment is already available.
It is important to note that the tenancy agreement must already be signed by the landlord, but not by the tenant.

Amount of heating costs
Total rent

Security deposit
The Jobcenter can grant the deposit on a loan basis upon application.
Loan basis means: you are lent the money and have to pay it back.
As a rule, this is unproblematic and is approved if the accommodation costs are reasonable.
The Jobcenter usually pays the deposit directly to the landlord or tenant.

The initial equipment includes furniture, curtains, mattresses, cooking utensils, dishes and, if not available in the apartment, stove, sink, refrigerator and washing machine.

question: What happens if you sign a contract that you don't understand?

Contracts in Germany

For example, if you want to use a smartphone, rent an apartment or work out at a gym, you must conclude a contract either verbally or in writing.

question: Where can I find support after my asylum decision?
context:

Decision on the asylum application
After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be recognized.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority.
The decision is negative
If your asylum application is rejected, you will receive a negative decision and a deportation warning.
Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
If you do not leave the country by this date, you may be forcibly deported.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the rejection, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receiving the decision.
Therefore, go immediately to the integration and refugee counseling service in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".
Voluntary departure
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for a new start in your country of origin.
You can get advice on voluntary departure here:

question: What are the consequences of illegal employment in Germany?
context:

Irregular and illegal employment
Work that is paid but not registered with the tax office and health insurance fund and for which no taxes and social security contributions are therefore paid is illegal and is referred to as "irregular employment" in Germany.
Fines and prison sentences are threatened!
If someone receives social benefits or unemployment benefit but still works and conceals this from the social welfare office, employment agency or job center, this is called illegal employment: You receive state benefits even though you are in paid employment.
This is prohibited and against the law.
A colloquial term for this is "moonlighting".
Always inform the office from which you receive benefits if you wish to take up work;
It is permitted to earn money while receiving benefits (benefits will then be recalculated), but you are obliged to declare any earnings and income immediately.
Taking up employment despite a work ban is also considered illegal employment.
Depending on the country of origin and reason for residence, illegal employment can lead to an indefinite ban on working!

All people are allowed to form their own opinions, express them freely and disseminate them.

Religion in Germany
Germany is a predominantly Christian country.
Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith.
Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
In the meantime, many people no longer have a denomination.
This means that you do not belong to any religious community or denomination.
Christianity continues to play a major role in Germany.
That is why there are also many statutory Christian holidays.
Other religious holidays are also observed at school.
Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays may be exempted from school.
This should be discussed with the school at an early stage.
Faith is a private matter in Germany.
State and religion are separate.
However, the state and religion work closely together.
For example, there are religious education classes at school.
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith.
Religious freedom is a valuable asset.
Religious freedom
Religious freedom is the law in Germany.
Every person has the right to choose and practice their own faith.
The Basic Law must not be violated in the process.
Religious freedom includes:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom not to be religious.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
People of different religions and beliefs are allowed to marry each other.
A marriage must be performed at the registry office.
Only then is it a legally valid marriage.
Any person may also marry within the framework of religion.
However, this is not legally binding in Germany.
The Basic Law can be read in nine languages (German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").

question: What rights are laid down in the Basic Law?
context:

The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that everyone has to abide by.
The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law.
It is a collection of 146 articles.
Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule.
These rules determine how we live together in Germany.
Fundamental rights protect the freedom of each individual.
They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalog of fundamental rights).
Here you will find the Basic Law in various languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that always apply to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every person has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally due to all human beings without distinction of any kind, such as skin color, gender, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, wealth, birth or other status.
There are 30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are worth the same.
Everyone is allowed to have their own opinion.
Right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these fundamental rights.
The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Demokratie für mich" (Democracy for me), in which these rules are clearly presented.

By applying for asylum, you start an asylum procedure.
It decides whether you are allowed to stay in Germany.
There are different forms of protection under German law.
This is because there are different forms of persecution.
In the asylum procedure, your situation is analysed in detail.
You will then be granted a form of protection.
You can find an overview of the forms of protection here.
Under the links you will find information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Entitlement to asylum
Politically persecuted people are granted asylum in Germany.
This is stated in the Basic Law (Art.
16 A).
You receive protection status if you are persecuted by the state in your home country because of
Your ethnicity
Your nationality
Your political convictions
your religion or
your membership of a particular social group (e.g. because of your sexual orientation).
Some people also fear punishment if they return to their home country.
This form of protection also applies in this case.
Find out more
Refugee protection
The Geneva Refugee Convention has defined who is considered a refugee.
The definition says: A refugee is outside the country of origin.
He or she is persecuted by a state or non-state because of one of the following characteristics
ethnicity
religion
nationality
political conviction
membership of a particular social group (e.g. due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: Section 3 para.
of the Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
Subsidiary protection applies to people who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin.
Or who cannot claim protection in their country of origin.
The threat can come from a governmental or non-governmental source.
These include
Death penalty
torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian due to indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: Section 4 (1) AsylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
the return would constitute a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: Section 60 (5) AufenthG, Section 60 (7) AufenthG
Learn more

question: What is the basic law that everyone living in Germany must follow?
context:
Grundgesetz (basic law) and human rights
Grundgesetz (basic law) and human rights
Everyone living in Germany must abide by the Grundgesetz (basic law) of the political and legal system.
The main legal basis of life in Germany is the Grundgesetz (basic law).
This is the constitution of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Under the Grundgesetz (basic law), every person living in Germany is, therefore, a free individual with a right to self-determination.
No distinctions may be made on the basis of gender, origin (ancestry, language, home), skin colour, religion, beliefs or philosophy, disability, age or sexual orientation.
Germany is a federal republic consisting of 16 Bundesländer (federal states).
Germany is a democratic state.
This means that all the power of the state comes from the people.
Principles of the basic law
Protection of human dignity
Article 1
(1) Human dignity shall be inviolable.
To respect and protect it shall be the duty of all state authority.
(...)
Personal freedoms
Article 2
(1) All persons shall have the right to free development of their personality insofar as they do not violate the rights of others or offend against the constitutional order or the moral law.
(...)
This also means the right to sexual self-determination.
This means:all persons can decide for themselves which sexual acts they want to participate in and nobody can be forced to do something they do not want to do.
Equality before the law
Article 3
(1) All persons shall be equal before the law.
(2) Men and women shall have equal rights.
The state shall promote the actual implementation of equal rights for women and men and take steps to eliminate disadvantages that exist today.
www.zanzu.de
(3) No person shall be favoured or disfavoured because of gender, parentage, race, language, homeland and origin, faith, or religious or political opinions.
No person shall be disfavoured because of disability.
Freedom of faith, conscience and creed
Article 4
(1) Freedom of faith and of conscience, and freedom to profess a religious or philosophical creed, shall be inviolable.
(...)
Freedom of expression
Article 5
(1) All persons shall have the right freely to express and disseminate their opinions in speech, writing, and pictures and to inform themselves without hindrance from generally accessible sources.
Freedom of the press and freedom of reporting by means of broadcasts and film shall be guaranteed.
There shall be no censorship.
(...)
Marriage and the family;
children born outside marriage
Article 6
(1) Marriage and the family shall enjoy the special protection of the state.
(...)

question: How can I find a pharmacy in Germany?
context:
Pharmacy and medicines
Pharmacies (Apotheken)
In Germany, you canonly get medicinesin pharmacies.
In other shops or in the doctor's office you will not get any medicine.
Every pharmacy can be recognised from the outside by the red A.
Pharmacies are openfrom Monday to Saturday.
The opening times vary according to each chemist.
If you urgently need medication outside normal opening hours, you will find a sign at every chemist with the name and address of the chemist which is open for emergencies.
Search for pharmacies near you
Search pharmacy emergency service
Medication
There are prescription and over-the-counter drugs.
You can only getprescription medicines if a doctor issues a prescription.
Prescription drugs are, for example, drugs for high blood pressure or diabetes and all antibiotics for bacterial infections.
You can getover-the-counter medicines at the pharmacy without a prescription.
So you don't have to see a doctor beforehand.
Over-the-counter drugs are, for example, drugs for colds and many drugs for pain.
Recipe colours:
Pink: This is the colour of the prescription sheet for people with statutory health insurance.
Such a prescription is valid for 28 days.
Green: On these prescription sheets, doctors recommend over-the-counter medicines.
Such a prescription is valid indefinitely.
Blue: This is the prescription sheet for privately insured persons.
Such a prescription is valid for three months in most cases.
Yellow: Narcotics are prescribed on these prescriptions, for example strong painkillers.
Such a prescription is valid for 7 days.
Cost of medicines
Statutory health insurance: Drugs (pink prescription) are partly paid by health insurance companies.
You have to pay a co-payment of at least 5 € yourself.
You do not have to pay this for children up to 18 years of age.
Medicines that do not require a prescription (for example, cough syrup) must be paid for by yourself (green or blue prescription).
Health care for asylum seekers: Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free.
Therefore, check with your doctor.

question: Who should get vaccinated against meningococcal type C?
context:
Further vaccination recommendations of the STIKO
1. TBE (early summer meningoencephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of a disease are inflammations of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Especially Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony are considered risk areas in Germany.
Especially in these areas, vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO.
All children can attend from the age of 1. The vaccination against TBE must be carried out before the child's 60th birthday.
2. Influenza (flu)
Influenza is contagious in a similar way to a normal cold (flu).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child or via objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
Complications such as pneumonia can occur in them.
The recommendation for annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find more information about the affected pre-existing conditionshere.
3. HPV (human papilloma viruses)
Papilloma viruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancers of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. Meningococcus
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents are particularly at risk.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccination against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via so-called droplet infection, i.e. for example via coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. Pneumococcus
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen of severe bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections and are especially dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations are recommended against pneumococci, which should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria, whooping cough.
6. Rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhoea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious, which is why almost all children contract it in the first five years - usually at the age of 2. Especially in infants, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration, which may have to be treated in hospital.
Rotaviruses are vaccinated two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age, the second at 3 months and the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the Corona virus is currently recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years only with the vaccine "Comirnaty" from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given at intervals of three to six weeks between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children in whose environment there are persons with a high risk of a severe COVID-19 course, if they themselves cannot be vaccinated or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without their own pre-existing conditions or pre-existing conditions of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
For more information on the affected pre-existing conditions, see:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the above vaccination recommendations here.

question: Is health insurance mandatory?
context:

In Germany, insurance is compulsory.
This means you have to be a member of a health insurance fund to see a doctor.
As soon as you have a residence title , you must register with a regular health insurance fund.
You can choose and change the health insurance company yourself.
You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are thus entitled to the same services as all residents in Germany.

Services during pregnancy

Costs

For therapies (for example, physiotherapy) and aids (for example, bandages) you have to pay a contribution yourself.
People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.
Please ask your health insurance company about this.
The costs of dental treatment are paid by the health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs of hospital treatment are also paid by the health insurance company.
However, you have to pay a daily hospital allowance of € 10for each dayspent in hospital.
People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.

question: What is the purpose of German courses for initial language orientation?
context:
German courses for initial language orientation
German courses for initial language orientation
The German courses for initial language orientation (also: initial orientation courses) provide both elementary knowledge of German as well as information about life in Germany.
They are a practical first step for participants in a new social environment and help with their orientation in everyday life.
One course comprises 300 lesson units, each 45 minutes long and covers topics such as “health/medical care”, “work”, “nursery/school”, “housing”, “orientation on site/traffic/mobility”.
Spoken communication is the main focus: Participants should learn as quickly as possible how to find their way around in everyday life.
In the case of initial orientation courses, it is also a question of teaching values.
Initial orientation courses are primarily intended for asylum seekers with an unclear prospect of permanent residence in Germany.
Provided that there are free places on the course, recognised asylum seekers, legally tolerated foreigners and asylum seekers with good prospects of permanent residence may also participate.
If you are still school age (6 to 15 years) or obliged to attend vocational college (16 to 21), you don’t attend the initial orientation course, but your school or educational facility.
If you are given access to an »» integration coursewhile participating in an initial orientation course, it is possible to switch to this course.
The people on the courses have very different educational backgrounds.
Illiterate people can attend the courses as well as university graduates.
Initial orientation courses are free.
The course language is German– interpreters are not present on the course.
Contact an »» Immigration Advice Centre or your »» Asylum and Integration counselling service on-site in your hostel.
They will help you to find a suitable course.
Find out more
People who are not eligible for this offer can contact the »» Integrationsberatungszentrum IBZ Sprache und Beruf (integration advice centre IBZ language and careers).
It organises supplementary German language courses.

question: What are the consequences of illegal employment in Germany?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
It can be punished with fines and prison!
If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment: A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
This is forbidden and against the law.
In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

School holidays
School holidays are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Autumn holidays: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).

Intercultural calendar

Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is moved forward one hour from winter to summer time.
From summer to winter time, the clock is set back by one hour.

If you drive a car in Germany, you must have a valid driving licence and always carry it with you.

You will also have to take a theoretical and practical exam.
Persons from EU/EEA states with a valid driving licence do not need to transfer their foreign driving licence.
